Plus, as some observers point out, tackling oil and gas-related methane emissions in developed countries is a matter of global equity.

by the U.S. House of Representatives committee on Science, Space, and Technology released last month. The report added that the rule could be ‚Äúan essential pillar of America‚Äôs drive to achieve the targets set forth in the Global Methane Pledge.‚Äù
And while the Supreme Court‚Äôs recent

ruling limited some of the environmental agency‚Äôs regulatory powers, Daniel Farber, law professor at the Center for Law, Energy, and the Environment at the University of California, Berkeley, said there‚Äôs no reason to believe that the judgment would impact proposed methane rule because it is ‚Äúa very routine exercise of EPA‚Äôs power to impose emission limitations on pollution sources.‚Äù

According to Farber, the Supreme Court ruling is intended to curb the EPA‚Äôs regulation of carbon dioxide from power plants, which is different from regular EPA regulations. ‚ÄúIn the court‚Äôs view, instead of regulating emissions at individual sources, EPA was asserting authority to control what energy sources would be used on the U.S. electricity grid,‚Äù said Farber. ‚ÄúThe methane regulations, on the other hand, are much closer to business as usual for EPA.‚Äù
A spokesperson for the EPA declined to weigh in on whether the proposed rule would be impacted by the

ruling. They noted, however, that the agency is also working on a supplemental proposal on the matter. ‚ÄúThe supplemental proposal is an important step in developing a final rule, which we expect to finalize within the next year,‚Äù they explained.
